loans.name: Yasin's Group

texts.en: K. Yasin is 66 years old, married and has seven children between the ages of 16 and 40. Three of his children are still in school and he also takes care of two orphans. K. opened a kiosk four years ago with money he saved from years of farming, and has applied for a loan to stock it with new merchandise to sell to his customers. His other goal is to build a house so that he can stop renting, since this is costly and difficult for him in his old age.

loans.use: To restock his kiosk with more goods.

loans.name: Zoraida

texts.en:
Zoraida C. lives in the village of San Antonio, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 45 years old, married and has five school-aged children. She makes a living by running a specialized retail store where she sells clothes and shoes. She has been in this business for more than three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Zoraida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to improve her life and expand her business opportunities. She is applying for a loan, her first, to buy new items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy new items and expand her product offerings

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita R. lives in the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old, married and has seven school-aged children. Lolita makes a living by selling dried fish and firewood. She is just started this small business.

Earlier this year, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and business opportunities. She has applied for this loan, her first, to buy new products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy new items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Fazirah's Group

texts.en: M. Fazirah is 27 years old, married and has three children between the ages of 2 and 9. She also takes care of two orphans, children of desceased siblings, including paying their school fees and other requirements. She makes a living by printing and binding books, but because of limited capital she has not been able to turn her business into a full secretarial service. She wants to acquire a new photocopier, and paper supplies to expand both her business and her income. Fazirah is hardworking and determined, and believes she will make it.

loans.use: To buy a photocopier and paper supplies for her business.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en: Miraim is a 47 year married with six children aged between 4and 20 years All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. Miriam resides and rents three roomed house where she is staying with four people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week. Miriam owns a poultry farm in Kawempe. She buys chicken feeds from Owino market She uses public transport to and from shopping.  She sells to all categories of people and on both retail and whole saleMiriam has been with MCDT for seven year servicing her twentieth loan. working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more chicken feeds and chicks. Miraim is aspiring of owning 700 chickens.

loans.use: To buy  more chicken feedsand chicks

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en: Jacinta owns a small shop in Kisumu where she sells blouses, skirts, shirts, pants and coats. She has requested her fourth loan from SMEP for KES 80,000 in order to increase her stock from markets in Nairobi and Busia. Jacinta’s shop is a roadside stall, not a permanent structure, and therefore business is often disrupted by rain. She would therefore like to one day move her business to a permanent shop in the city center. Jacinta is a mother of a 5-year old girl and describes herself as hard-working and polite.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda is 47 years old and she manages a sari-sari store (community-based store) in their village.  She wants her business to expand and earn bigger income in order to support the daily needs of her family.  Her weekly business income from her store is around PHP 2,000, which she uses as rolling capital for her business and as daily school allowance for her children.  She would like to avail a loan of PHP 10,000 from Kiva lenders to purchase some grocery items to retail in her store. She believes that through the support of the lenders, her business will be on the right track as she continues to persevere towards the success of her business.  

She is married to Domingo, a farmer, and they have two children.  Their eldest is a college student and their youngest is now a senior high school student. They are residing at Barangay Namnama Cabatuan, Isabela, a rural and plain area where farming is the major source of income for most of the residents.

loans.use: Purchase grocery items

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie M. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Rosalie is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Rosalie owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosalie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Musa's Group

texts.en: B. Musa is the leader of his lending group in Jinja. He is a married man of 15 years and has nine children of his own and he takes care of three orphans. He is a businessman involved in the buying and selling of produce from Jinja Central market for nine years and he is able to make 400,000 UGX profit per month. His previous business was selling ground nuts in a glass and this changed because the current business is more profitable. Among his produce, he deals in the buying and selling of millet, ground nuts, beans and soya beans and he hopes to include others. He is good at managing his books and he has a dream of building his own full-fledged house and getting a better education for his children. He needs a loan to partly buy more produce for his business and also buy more building materials to build his house. Musa is indeed a very hardworking man.

loans.use: Buying more stock of produce for increased sales

loans.name: Arthur

texts.en: Arthur is a father of three who owns a small shop in a residential area of Kisumu. Arthur has been in this business for the past nine years, selling sodas, sugar, cooking oil, rice, eggs, and other staples. Previously, Arthur worked a variety of small jobs that enabled him to save enough money to start his business. Although Arthur faces several business challenges, including price fluctuations and security, he has already successfully repaid six loans to SMEP. He has just requested a new loan of KES 70,000 in order to increase the stock of foodstuffs in his shop.  Arthur describes himself as friendly, humble, practical, and faithful.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Melba

texts.en:
Melba C. is from the village of Lingating, Baungon Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Melba is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Melba owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Melba has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melba joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melba is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Melba from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is a 49 year-old father of five who owns and runs a tailoring business in Kisumu. Charles specializes in men’s suits, and is beginning to produce women’s suits as well. He sells the suits both retail and wholesale to other shops. Charles has owned his tailoring business for the past 21 years, and he now employs 15 people. Charles is a true businessman; he also owns residential houses and farms. He has successfully repaid four loans with SMEP, and has currently requested a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase additional fabric and boost production. In the future, Charles hopes to move into the manufacturing sector as his scale of production continues to increase. He would like to educate his children and give them the opportunity to achieve whatever they may desire. Charles describes himself as reliable, hard-working, and a good manager.

loans.use: Purchase materials

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina has been working patiently to provide the needs of her children. She is engaged in a retail business but she still does not have her own stall where she can display her products.  She admits that her daily profits are not sufficient to meet their daily needs. For this reason, she is also working as a stay-out housemaid and accepts laundry in their village to earn additional income. With the business she is engaged in, she is accumulating an income which is sufficient for her family and sometimes providing for other needs of her grandchildren.

As a businesswoman, Martina would like to expand her retailing business to be more profitable and somehow develop her own retail stall where she could display her products.  She hopes to borrow a loan of PHP 4,000 from the Kiva lenders.  She will use the loan to purchase more stock for her store that will result in an income increase.  Since she is getting old, she hopes that she can have good health so she can pursue helping her family. Two of her children are already married but she still supports her grandchildren.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is a single parent.  She was gifted with one daughter named Janice, 11 years old.  They live peacefully in the village of Punit Benito Soliven, Isabela. Being a single parent has been hard for her because she is the only one working and providing all the needs of her child. But she never take it as a reason to give up, instead, she works hard and is strives to succeed in her business.

Pacita is working diligently in her general store business which she owns and manages for already eight years. She is aspiring for the expansion and for her business to become more progressive. She hopes that she can avail a loan of PHP5, 000 to be used as her additional capital to make her business grow.  She is planning to purchase more commodities like fish, vegetables and additional grocery items for her general store.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Airene

texts.en:
Airene S. is from the village of Lingating, Baungon Bukidnon. She is 20 years old. Airene is single and has one infant child. To make a living, Airene owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Airene has been engaged in her business for more than one year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Airene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Airene is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Airene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Levita

texts.en:
Levita is engaged in the vending business.  She sells vegetables, fish and dressed chicken in their village using her three wheeled bicycle as her service.  Through her business, she was able to send her children to school and finish their high school education.  It was not t easy for her to gain sufficient income for them to pursue their studies in college because she is the only one looking for money to support all of them. Levita wanted to expand her business and increase her products in order to gain more profit. Thus, she wanted to avail a loan amounting to PHP5, 000 for the growth of rolling store business that very helpful in their daily living.

Levita is 52 years old and already a widow.  She have three children and they are living in Roxas Naguilian, Isabela.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Molly

texts.en:
Molly N. is currently in the business of selling beer at the bar and is requesting a loan to improve on the stock.  Molly is 25 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant . She has 2 children and her children do not go to school. 

 With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to esterblish distilation of local alcohol for sale.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: improve on the stock

loans.name: Montesa

texts.en:
Montesa is 38 years old.  She is a businesswoman from the village of Cabisera 9-11, Ilagan, Isabela. She works diligently in her business to provide for the other needs of her family. Working to help her hog raising business progress is her way to help her husband in his agriculture business. They have two children and the couple aspires to give them a good future ahead of them which they believe could easily be achieved by acquiring a complete education. 

Montesa makes a living by engaging herself in hog raising and retailing of gasoline in the store of her older sister in their village. Montesa wanted to grow her hog raising business and also to have additional capital for her gasoline retailing business. For this reason, she is requesting to avail a loan of PHP 18,000 for the expansion of her business. She hopes that Kiva lenders will support her in the business to give her family a good future through her business.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita P. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Amelita is married and has 6 older children. To make a living, Amelita owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling different goods in the local community. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Amelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Amelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Devotha

texts.en:
Devotha is a member of the Gangilonga borrower group in Kinyanambo , Iringa. She is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 14, and 4 years old.

Devotha has owned a business for 3 years, she works 10 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Devotha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Devotha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for sale

loans.name: Stenely

texts.en:
Stenely E. is already 54 years old and she has three children. They are not yet married. The eldest is already a college graduate and their two younger children are still studying in college and in high school. They are harmoniously residing at Barangay Namnama, Cabatuan Isabela, an agricultural-based community.

Stenely is managing a poultry-raising business. She raises commercial broilers in their house and later sells them at live weight for PHP120/kilo. She also has been selling frozen foods in their village for almost ten years now and is thankful for maintaining the business for that long. She hopes to further improve her livelihood for her family's better living. In this regard, Stenely wants to take out a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP10,000 as additional working capital for her poultry and sales businesses.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji W. is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to open up a bakery. Keji is 40 years old and is widowed. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase motorbikes for sale.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: open up a bakery

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena dreams of a better life for her family. She is willing to do everything just to have her children finish their studies. She is now 49 years old and married to Ruben, a farmer. They have four children: Rodolfo, who has already finished his Criminology course and now works as a Security guard in Manila; and Rowena, a graduating student in college. Magdalena's third child and her youngest child already stopped studying to give way to their sister. Magdalena plans to pursue sending them to college after Rowena finishes her college education.

Magdalena is engaged in managing a general store. From this business, she is generating a net income of PHP100 daily. Because of her low income, Magdalena decided to venture into selling used clothes or second-hand clothing to have additional income to meet the needs of her family. She would like to access a loan amounting to PHP 8,000 from KIVA lenders. She will use the loan to further expand her business to able earn a bigger income. She hopes that her business will be supported by the lenders for it is chance of making her business progressive.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Siwema

texts.en:
Siwema is a member of the  Gangilonga borrower group in Kinayanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 9, and 2 years old.

Siwema has owned a food business selling local beer for 3 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Siwema`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 100,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for making local beer.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Siwema hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for local beer

loans.name: Yangi

texts.en:
Yangi R. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and green vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil and onions to sell. Yangi is 22 years old and is married to a husband who is a fisherman. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase cooking oil and onions to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria hails from beautiful Teresa, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is a mother to three and all are already of legal age. She is 65 years old already, but strong and determined to have her own source of income.
She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Phillipines. Since she is already old, she wants a business that fits her capacity. She needs capital to continue her rug-making business. She makes the rugs and sells them to businessmen who send them to market.
Now on her fifth loan, she proposes a loan of 25,000 pesos as additional capital for her rug-making business. She will use the loan to pay for assorted cloths used as raw materials, threads and needles.
She is very thankful that KIVA people through ASHI are able to share in the poverty alleviation program.

loans.use: To buy cloth, thread and needles.

loans.name: Makenly

texts.en:
Makenly is always hoping that they can uplift their poor living conditions through their transport business that her husband operates in their village.  She is now 25 years old, married and blessed with a child named Angelica, three years old.  The couple hopes to give their only child a good future by sending her to school until college.  Their family lives in Cabisera 9 - 11, Ilagan, Isabela, a mountainous village where upland farming is the common source of livelihood for most of the residents.

To help her husband with his transportation business, Makenly keeps herself busy with her backyard gardening. She plants different kinds of vegetables and retails them in the village.  She would like to avail a loan of at least PHP5,000 to be used to purchase fertilizers and medicines for her vegetables. She would also use it to maintain her husband’s passenger tricycle to keep the transport business safe and away from harm or accident. She hopes that her loan will be approved for it will be quite beneficial for her family.

loans.use: To maintain their tricycle

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia is a member of the Gangilonga borrower group in Knyanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 1 year old.

Lidia has owned a business for 2 years , she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 70,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Lidia  first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 100,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities for local beer.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Lidia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy mor comodities for local beer

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon resides in the village of Punit, Benito Soliven, Isabela. Her husband works as a laborer and they have four children. Their eldest is Christian, eight years old; Jericho, seven years old; John Carl, two years old and Princess Joy, seven months old. They have a happy family despite their poor living conditions. She and her husband join hands to provide the needs of their children.

Corazon has a small pigpen at the back of their house and she started raising hogs early this year. This business is quite good because she considers it as an investment that she can use in times of emergency and to support the needs of their children.  She is requesting the amount of PHP4,000 to maintain her hog-raising business and somehow improve it. To generate income everyday, she also offers manicure and pedicure services to everyone in the village who is interested in paying her service fee of PHP40/person only. This gives her a daily income that is helpful in meeting her family daily needs.

loans.use: To maintain and improve her hog-raising business

loans.name: Shida

texts.en:
Shida is a member of the Gangilonga borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 8 years old. 

Shida has owned a Grocery business for 3 years, she works 8 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Shida`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more drinks for Grocery business.

With the additional profit she gains from  the use of this loan, Shida hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more Drinks

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann B. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 21 years old. Mary Ann is married and has three very young children. To make a living, Mary Ann owns and operates a retail store in the local community where she sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp. Mary Ann has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Mary Ann joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her product line.

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina helps her husband in manufacturing folding beds. She is the one purchasing good quality steel from junk shops and other needed materials in the market. The couple has been in this kind of business for 10 years and they want to produce more for its expansion. 

They sell the folding beds they produce in the market and in some villages using their tricycle. Rufina would like to borrow a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos to be used as additional capital in expanding their business. The loan will be a big help in making the couple’s business more profitable. 

Rufina is 43 years old and married to Rogelio, who is a very responsible husband and is diligent in assembling folding beds. Rufina’s two children are now married and they have their own families. The couple is still providing them with their other needs for the sake of their grandchildren. She hopes that their business will become more successful to be able to provide them more with their needs.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa is 43 years old and she is already a widow. Her husband passed away eight years ago. She lives in the village of Roxas, Naguilian, Isabela. They only had one child, Jilbert Lui, who is 8 years old. She serves as a father and mother to her son. Luisa aspires to give her child a complete education, which he could treasure for his whole life. This is the reason why she never loses hope.

Luisa is requesting a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos to obtain additional capital to improve her general store. She is planning to purchase more business commodities to display and sell in her small variety store. She hopes that her business will be maintained and grow continuously so that she’ll be ready to send her son to a higher level of education in the future.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley D. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Shirley is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Shirley operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing pedicab services to transport passengers to local communities. Shirley is also a worker of Del Monte Philippines. She has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 1,500 Philippine pesos (about $32) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Shirley joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the first loan taken out by Shirley from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji A. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at the resturant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs, cook and sell.

  Keji is 32 years old and is Married with a husband that is a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a lorry.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Erina

texts.en:
Erina is a member of the Idope borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is single and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 18, 9 years old.

Erina has owned a  business for 4 years, she works 3 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Erina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzanian, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more chicken for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Erina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for sale

loans.name: Ichinnorov

texts.en:
Ichinnorov is 29 years old and lives with her husband in Uyurkhangai province in Mongolia. She and her husband live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Ichinnorov makes felt products such as slippers, hats and seat cushions which are sold at a souvenir stand in front of Erdene-Zuu, an ancient Mongolian Buddhist monastery. She began her craft business in 2004 and has since expanded her product line to include deels, traditional Mongolian coats.

Ichinnorov wants to increase her business and her profits by owning her own stand outside of Erdene-Zuu instead of relying on another person to sell her products. She is proud of her sewing abilities and would like to expand her product line even further so that she can broaden her customer base. She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan in order to buy more felt and sewing supplies in order to keep her business growing.

loans.use: To buy more felt and sewing supplies

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is 45 years old.  She lives in the village of Roxas Naguilian, Isabela. She is married to Panchito, who is now 42 years old and was working as a carpenter in their village. They have four children: Ramoncito – 22 years old, graduated in college with the degree in Information Technology; Arjie – 20 years old, presently working as company driver in Cauayan; Gerald – 18 years old, taking up a two-year course in Criminology and lastly Angelica – 16 years old, also studying in college taking up a degree in Hotel and Restaurant Management. 

Anecita is engaged in rice retailing business in their village. She is also accepting a laundry service where she manually washes clothes. She is patiently doing her work to able help her husband in bringing income to their family. She is also aiming to provide complete education to all her children which for her, is the best thing she could offer them by working hard in her rice retailing and accepting laundry service.  

Anecita is wishing to avail a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP4, 000 for the expansion of her rice retailing business. She is planning to purchase sacks of rice to be retailed. She is hoping that her product will be continuously available in order to provide the needs of the people in their community and her family daily needs. This will also bring them more profit which is very indispensable to the education of their children.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda, now 59 years old, lives in the village of Punit Benito Soliven, Isabela.  She has been a widow for four years, while her only son passed away due to an accident already fifteen years ago. 

To keep herself busy, Erlinda got involved in the food snacks sales business: she sells banana cue and ripe banana, vegetables, fruit, and meat from a stall in front of her house.  She would now like to expand the business in order to be able to save some income for future emergency use.  Erlinda is requesting a loan of PHP4,000 to use as additional capital for the business expansion.  ”As long as I have the strength to work, I will do my best to be productive while enjoying life, because it is so short,” she also shares.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia B. is currently in the business of selling beer and soda and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer and some wines to sell.  

Julia is 35 years old and is Married with a husband that is a business man. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more crates of beer and some wines to sell

loans.name: Idda

texts.en:
Idda is a member of the Idope borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 22 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. her child is 4 years old.

Idda has owned a Food business selling chicken for 2 years, she works 7 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Idda`s  first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy chicken for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Idda hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for sale

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 41 years old and married to Wilmer, 30 years old and working in Saudi Arabia as a house carpenter. With the difficulties in life, they have decided to live and work away from each other and accept greater opportunity in other country. They have four children and three of them are already studying.  They are hoping that their sacrifices as parents would be meaningful and be appreciated by their children someday. She hopes to see all of them with good future.

Gloria is engaged in the buy and sell business of vegetables in the market. She buys vegetables in their village very early in the morning and then sells the products in the public market. She is requesting for a loan from KIVA lenders a loan of PHP5,000 that will serve as business capital.  She hopes that her retailing business of vegetables will further expand to be more profitable. Through the said business, Gloria is helping her husband in providing the needs of their family as well as the needs of their children.  She hopes that through her own sacrifices in the business, she could be a productive business woman someday.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Cherry Mae

texts.en:
Cherry Mae D. C., 19, is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. Cherry Mae is married and has a small child.  To make a living, she recently started her own business venture in the services sector, transporting passengers from the local community.

In 2009, Cherry Mae joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Now she is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services that her business is providing.  This will be Cherry Mae's first loan from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it even further. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of materials needed to expand the services provided

loans.name: Precy

texts.en: Precy S., 36 years old, is married to Eduardo who works as an electrician.  They have four children, three of whom have already finished their studies, while the youngest one, a 3-year-old, is at school.  To make a living, Precy has been managing a general store in the village of Namnama Cabatuan, Isabela for almost six years, and has been able to earn a weekly income of about PHP1,000, which she spends on the maintenance of her business and on family needs. Precy would now like to borrow PHP6,000 to add to her working capital in order to be able to improve her business.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is already 31 years old and is married to Allan, a tricycle driver in the town of Ilagan, Isabela. They have only one four-year-old child. The couple joined hands to provide adequate support to their family, and especially their child. The couple’s goal in life is to give their child a complete education, which the child will treasure. 

Thelma would like to avail a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 for the repair and maintenance of the passenger tricycle that her husband operates. She is hoping that her loan will be approved because it will greatly help in the maintenance of their transportation business. Thelma also desires to have more working capital because sometimes, if her husband has excess income from driving, she uses the money to sell used clothes in their village. Unfortunately, she couldn’t afford to maintain her own business due to insufficient business capital. She just hopes that lenders will lend them the amount requested.

loans.use: Maintain and repair tricycle

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane J. is currently in the business of selling cold drinks in her shop and is requesting a loan to purchase another refrigerator to keep more drinks cold. Jane is 28 years old and is married to a husband who works as a policeman. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.use: Purchase another refrigerator to keep drinks cold

loans.name: Esther Wanjiku

texts.en:
Esther K. is a 30-year-old single lady whose business is selling different electrical items. She operates her business in Dagoretti Market, which has a lot of electronics dealers. She has been in the retail business for about one year. Esther was introduced to KADET by a friend despite having no previous borrowing history with any other MFI. She intends to use the loan to grow the inventory in her electronics retail shop. In future she hopes to sell to bigger institutions and other shops. 

About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Increasing inventory

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en:
Zuhura is a member of the Idope borrower group in Kinyambo, Iringa. She is 28 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 11, 3 years old.

Zuhura has owned a food business selling chicken for 3 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly  profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings. 

This is Zuhura`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more chicken for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zuhura hopes to save more money, pay school fees, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chicken  for sale

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia is married to Abner, who works as a government employee. She is 45 years old and is blessed with three children. Haydee, her eldest, is currently living in Jordan and working as a factory worker. Hayleen is a fourth-year college student. Absel, the youngest, is also in college. Sending them to college is very costly. Celia hopes that her children will finish their studies with her financial support. 

To help her husband in providing for the growing needs of their children, Celia began selling beauty soaps. She gets orders from people in her community and then purchases her products in Tumauini, Isabela. She also maintains a hog-raising business in their home. To further grow both of her businesses, Celia is requesting a loan for PHP9,000 from Kiva lenders. She hopes to obtain a loan from lenders to have her business raise more capital. She plans to purchase stocks of beauty soaps and feed supply for her hogs to help them grow bigger. She hopes that her loan will be approved so that her businesses will remain stable.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Milagrosa

texts.en:
Milagrosa R. owns and operates a clothing business buying and selling used clothing, locally known as "Ukay-Ukay", to local community members. She is 35 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. Milagrosa has been in this business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Milagrosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Milagrosa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be Milagrosa's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a used clothing business

loans.name: Juvilyn

texts.en:
Juvilyn manages a vending business situated in the school canteen.  She sells different snacks like banana cue on stick and other snacks for children. She also brings her products in front of their house whenever she is not in the school. She wanted to generate income everyday because she needs funds to meet the daily needs of her family. 

Juvilyn is asking for financial support from KIVA lenders for the improvement of her business. She then decided to ask for financial assistance amounting to PHP5, 000 loans. She wishes for its development to further increase her daily income. She have two children and they were both studying.  She is glad that her husband is always there to support their business and she prays that they will be given the chance to further expand their business.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel K. is a married businessman, age 37, and the father of one daughter. He sells shoes at Uthiru Center where most of his clients are. He brings in a monthly profit of approximately 30,000 KES. He has been in this business for about 14 years.

Samuel has never borrowed from any financial institution. This loan from KADET will be used to expand his business. His intention is to expand his business to a level where he can be an importer of secondhand shoes from other countries. He also hopes to buy land and build his own house.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To expanding a shoe business

loans.name: Donnabel

texts.en:
Donnabel is 39 years old. She lives happily with her husband, Ludovico, who is 42 years old and a farmer. She is a mother to two girls, Loraine and Jobelle. She lives in the busy town of Morong, Rizal Province in the Philippines.

With the support of her husband, she is engaged in farming. Since Philippines is an agricultural country, most of the folks are engaged in farming and rice is the staple food for every Filipino. But to farm, one also needs capital. A farmer will invest her money for almost three months from planting until the rice harvest. Farming brings her enough income and generates food. However, she needs money to sustain her farm needs.

In 2003, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with hopes of having access to capital. Her previous loans, over the past five years, were spent on farm supplies. Now on her 8th loan, she proposes a loan of 12,000 pesos to use as additional capital for her farming business. Specifically, the loan will be used to rent a hand tractor, and to pay for pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers and labor.

She hopes that, with the help of ASHI and trust of KIVA, she can improve her farm, buy some farm equipment, and also to send her children to school until they finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: To rent a hand tractor and pay for pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers and labor.

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji S. bakes and sells bread. She is requesting a loan to purchase baking materials. Keji is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 5 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy baking materials

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer is 22 years old. She is a young mother with a one-year-old baby named Jerome. She is happily married to Renato Jr., a passenger-tricycle driver. They are presently residing in Cabisera 9-11 of Ilagan, Isabela, an isolated and mountainous village. Jennifer feels the need to work hard to sustain their daily needs. Sometimes, when there is someone to take care of her child, she works on a farm just to obtain a daily income from farm labor amounting to $2.25 a day. She hopes that someday she’ll be able to manage her own business. For now, Jennifer is requesting a loan amounting to PHP18,000 for the maintenance and repair of her husband's passenger-tricycle. She hopes that lenders will support the needs of her family by helping to increase their income.

loans.use: Tricycle repair

loans.name: Yusta

texts.en:
Yusta is a member of the Idope borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is single and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 25,20 years old.She also cares for other 1 dependent.

Yusta has owned a shop business for 5 years, she works 10 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Yusta`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities like rice, cooking oil etc.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Yusta hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shop commodities

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is 35 years old and lives in the village of Punit Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is married to Jerold, a government employee. The couple is blessed with four children, three of whom are in school. They are: Jecel - 14 years old; Jennifer - ten years old; Christine Joy – five years old, and Gerald Paul – two years old. Just like other parents, Cecilia is hoping to send her children on to higher levels of education someday. She is hoping that with the help of her business she will be able to finance their schooling.

Cecilia is engaged in a retail business where she sells different snacks in the school canteen located in their village.  Aside from cooked snacks, she also sells other grocery items which the students like. She also sells vegetables and fruits in their village on the weekend. She knows that her business can grow if she has sufficient business capital. For this reason, Cecilia is hoping for a loan amounting to PHP5,000 for her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Cecilia Ndunge

texts.en:
Cecilia M. is a lady who separated from her husband and she has six children namely David, Elijah, Grace, Rhoda and Dorcas who are 29 27 24 21 and 12 years respectively.

Cecilia has been in the goods distribution business for the last 10 years. She operates her business in the open air market within Nairobi where retailers come to buy goods for sale.

The client was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she has no previous credit history. 
Cecelia plans to use the loan to add stock of goods including carrots, garlic, ginger, irish potatoes and to get more orders to supply to retailers in various estates. With the extra profit, the client  intends to expand the business where she will be transporting produce from up-county. 

Cecilia beleives she is persistent and determined thus her future aspirations are to own a lorry to transport the produce.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Adding more stock

loans.name: Maybel Ruth

texts.en:
Maybel Ruth R. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 20 years old and single with one infant child. To make a living, Maybel Ruth grows fruits and vegetables that she sells. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $75 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Maybel Ruth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maybel Ruth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be invested in her business. This loan will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by the loan to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
