loans.use: To purchase more dairy cows and feed.

loans.name: Laulensia

texts.en:
Laulensia is a member of the Tanganyika borrower group in Kinayanambo, Iringa. She is married and a mother of 4 children. her children are 18, 16, 10, 5 years old. She also cares for other 1 dependent.

Laulensia has owned a business selling local beer for 10 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly  profits approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Laulensia`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for local beer.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Laulensia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy maize for local beer

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.fr: G. Rosaline est née le 16/01/1976 à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Rosaline est mariée à DE SOUZA Aimé, un mécanicien. Ce couple a à sa charge trois enfants tous scolarisés dont deux sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis vingt deux ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou. C’est le mari de Rosaline qui assure les charges de la famille. Ceci permet à Rosaline d’utiliser les revenus de son activité pour mieux développer celle-ci. Rosaline vend de façon ambulante des sacs d’écolier, des fournitures scolaires, des chaussures, des savons et des fruits. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Rosaline achète ses produits. Rosaline a déjà quinze ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Rosaline a déjà eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour continuer à développer son activité, Rosaline demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
G. Rosaline was born on January 16, 1976 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  She is married to SOUZA Aimé, a mechanic.  This couple has three children to support.  Two of them are their own;  all three are in school.  For 22 years, the family has been residing in Fridjrossè Kpota, a district of Cotonou.  Rosaline's husband is the one who ensure that family expenses are covered.  This allows Rosaline to use the revenues from her business to develop it further.  Rosaline goes door-to-door to sell her bags, necklaces, school supplies, shoes, soaps, and fruit. Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin, is where Rosaline buys her goods.  She already has 15 years of experience in this business.  She had two ALIDé loans before that she has repaid.  She was able to use them to raise her level of business.  To continue to develop her business, Rosaline is asking for a third loan to bolster her working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags and school supplies

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sharof

texts.en:
This is I. Sharof, who is married with 4 children. He is 56 years old and lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. He has a retail shop and he is the one to support his family with this business. Sharof sells spare parts for foreign cars. He has been involved in this business for more than 13 years. He provides the cars with spare parts and his family with the necessary food and needs. Sharof has a great demand for his spare parts thus he wants to buy more spare parts in order to be in requisition of his clients. He wants to take out an individual loan of $1000 USD to buy more spare parts and enlarge his shop to meet the requirement of his clients and make a good income for his family. Sharof is happy about this loan and would like to thank everyone for the trust and support.

loans.use: Purchasing of the spare parts for car in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Armando

texts.en:
Mr. Armando C. is a 36-year-old married man. He is from Candida, Bi-ao, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. He and his wife started a small sari-sari (general) store with capital of PHP 3,000 from his first loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Now after a year, the couple has ventured into the food business by putting up a cafeteria inside the public market. The cafeteria is managed by his wife while Mr. Armado C. drives a passenger tricycle (motorcycle with a side car) which he uses to shuttle passengers around the town, very much like a taxi. Armando is borrowing PHP 20,000 for his 10th loan cycle to buy spare parts for the repair and maintenance of his tricycle, so that he can continue earning a good income from his transport venture.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: For repair and maintenance of his motorcycle.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace N. is a 37-year-old business woman who has been in the clothing business for over six years. She has two children. She is using the loan to invest in her business by purchasing more stock of clothes. She wishes to work very hard to obtain a house in future.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Abdikodir

texts.en:
S. Abdikodir is 40 years old. He is married with three children. Abdikodir is running the café where he is cooking the national dishes. Being very good and experienced cook, Abdikodir managed to make his business successful. The incomes from the business are used by Abdikodir for improving the living conditions of the family. He also is dreaming to be able to educate his children in the Institutes and Universities. Now Abdikodir is planning to purchase refrigerator and other necessary things for expanding his cafe to attract the more new clients and keep the old ones. For this he requests $1500 US Dollars. Abdikodir thanks all for support and promises to be precise in loan payment.

texts.en:
Komiljon is married with three children. Nine years ago he observed that his neighborhood needed a grocery store, so he started one in order to improve his family's quality of life and offer his children a good education. Komiljon started out selling basic necessities and little by little he has added more variety to his business. Today he offers a wide variety of products. He has grown his business with the help of his wife and children. In order to improve the quality of service and meet the demands of his customers, Komiljon is now requesting a $2000 loan which he will use to purchase merchandise. Please help this family improve their life by contributing to the growth of their business. They are sincerely grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Olga

texts.en: Olga K. is a 27-year-old married woman with one child. She has a retail shop in the Mengo area and has been operating this business for over two years. She requests a loan so she can offer customers some new items in her store and to buy more stock of existing items such as drinks, rice, plastics, soap, and sugar. She strives to be a good and prosperous business woman.

loans.use: To stock her shop.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal  and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.  Grace is 48 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant . She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build charcoal store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Chadassi

texts.fr: H. Chadassi est née vers 1953 à Ouidah. Chadassi est veuve. Chadassi a à sa charge cinq enfants tous scolarisés dont trois sont les leurs. Chadassi réside depuis vingt huit ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Chadassi supporte ses charges et celles de sa famille. Chadassi vend des tissus et des bols sur commande et à crédit. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Chadassi achète ses produits. Chadassi a déjà cinq d’expérience dans cette activité. Chadassi a déjà eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour continuer à développer son activité, Chadassi demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
H. Chadassi was born around 1953 in Ouidah.  Chadassi is a widow.  She has five children to support.  Three of them are her own; all five are in school.  For 20 years, she has been residing in Fridjrossè Kpota, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  Thanks to the income from her business, she is meeting her own expenses and those of her family. Chadassi sells cloth and bowls by special order and on credit. Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin, is where she purchases her goods.  She already has five years of experience in this business. She had two loans with ALIDé before and has repaid them.  She was able to use them to raise her level of business.  To continue to develop her business, Chadassi is asking for a third loan to bolster her working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plastic kitchen utensils

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth owns a small retail shop called JB Shop in Thika, just outside Nairobi. She has requested a loan of KES 80,000 in order to buy additional stock of food items. Her shop is located along a major highway, and business has been doing well. Elizabeth also owns several rental homes which allow her to bring in additional income. She hopes to one day own a supermarket. Elizabeth is a mother to a 3-year old boy and describes herself as loving and hard-working.

loans.use: Increase stock in her shop.

loans.name: Loice

texts.en: K. Loice has a Mimi super market in Nateete area. She is a dynamic lady of twenty-nine years old. She is married with one child. She has been doing this business for four years. She is using the loan to purchase variety of supermarket items such as kitchen stuffs, utensils, food, cereals, fruits, drinks, to mention but a few to expand the business for more customers. Her aim is to educate her child in good schools up to university level.

loans.use: To purchase varienty supermarket items such as kitchen stuffs, utensils, food, cereals, fruits, drinks, to mention but a few to expand the business for more customers.

loans.name: Ifou

texts.en:
Ifou M. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables, oranges, and similar items and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of salt to sell.  Ifou is 29 years old and married. Her husband is a teacher. They have three children who all attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to open up a shop.

About BRAC:
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of salt to sell.

loans.name: Celeste Mucavela

texts.pt:
Celeste nasceu no distrito da namaacha, tem 42 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 5 filhos com idades compreendidas entre 16 e trinta anos, todos encontrando se a estudar na excepcao dos dois mais velhos. Estudou ate 5 classe tendo parado devido à falta de condições financeiras por parte dos pais, no tempo colonial.

Cresceu na companhia dos seus progenitores no distrito de namaacha na zona de mafuiane e só saiu da mesma após o casamento e passou a viver no distrito de boane com o seu marido que é pensionista militar. Vive na casa própria com os três filhos mais novos e sem ninguém mais por sustentar. Faz negocio num estabelecimento comercial de pequena escala na zona da sua residência. Aprendeu a fazer esta actividade com suas amigas no ano 2000. Vende diversos produtos de mercearia (açúcar, pipocas, sabão, biscoites, produtos de beleza, higiene e outros) e tem rendimento mensal aproximado de 6.000,00MT que aplica no sustento da família e também poupa algum valor no esquema tradicional de poupança rotativa. ( xitque).

Este é o segundo empréstimo da Celeste no valor de 20.000,00MT para compra e venda de produtos de primeira necessidade (pipoca, sabão, biscoite produtos de beleza e outros). Acha que o aumento do volume do negocio poderá ganhar mais dinheiro e satisfação dos seus clientes. O primeiro empréstimo foi de 15.000,00MT para o exercício da mesma actividade.

Teve informações sobre a Hluvuku-Adsema através de vizinhos e clientes da instituição.
Propõe se, tal como no credito anterior, a reembolsar o empréstimo sem problemas para poder aceder a mais créditos com objectivo de fazer crescer o negocio e seu estabelecimento comercial.
texts.en:
Celeste was born in the district of Namaacha. She is 42; is married; and is the mother of 5 children, whose ages range from 16- to 30-years-old. All of them are in school except for the two oldest. Celeste studied through 5th grade and had to stop because of the financial situation of her parents during the Portuguese colonial rule. She grew up in the company of her two parents in the district of Namaacha in the Mafuiane region. She only left there after she got married and went to live in the district of Boane with her husband. He is in the military. She lives in her own home with her three youngest children, and she doesn't have any additional family members to support. She has her small business in the same area as her home. She learned to do this activity with her friends in the year 2000. She sells various products such as sugar, popcorn, cookies, beauty products, hygiene products, etc. She has a monthly income of 6,000 meticais, which she puts towards supporting her family. She also saves some money through a traditional savings group, which is known as xitque. This is Celeste's second loan, and it is for 20,000 meticais. She will use it to buy and sell basic products (popcorn, soap, cookies, beauty products, etc.). She believes that by raising the volume of her business, she will be able to earn more money and increase the satisfaction of her customers. Her first loan was for 15,000 meticais, which she used for the same purpose. She received information about Hluvuku-Adsema through neighbors and other clients of the institution. She is promising, just as with her previous credit, to repay the loan without any problems to be able to receive more credits in the future with the objective of growing her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise (cookies, sugar, flour, etc.)

loans.name: Ikuju

texts.en:
Ikuju R. is currently in the business of selling milk and cheese and is requesting a loan to open up a shop.  Ikuju is 29 years old and married.  Her husband is a cattle keeper. They have two children.  With the extra profits she will earn from her shop, she hopes to be able to construct a house which she will rent out.

About BRAC:
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop.

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is a member of the Ndiuka borrower group in Ruaha, Iringa. She is 28 year old woman, she is single and a mother of 1 child. her child is 2 years 10 years old. She also cares for other 1 dependent.

Zena has owned a shop business selling soap, cooking oil, sugar for 2 years , she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profits approximately 50,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Zena`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more Shop commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zena hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shop commodities

loans.name: Aurea Alexandre

texts.pt:
Aurea nasceu na província nortenha da Zambezia, na cidade de quelimane, de 29 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 2 filhos de com idades compreendidas entre os seis meses e dez anos. Estudou ate 10 classe tendo parado por motivos de doença respiratória. Vive em casa própria com os filhos e sustenta também a sua mãe que encontra se a viver na província natal da zambezia, enviando lhe dinheiro no final de cada mês.

Não cresceu na companhia dos seus progenitores. Saiu ainda criança para viver na província de inhambane em casa de familiares e mais tarde na cidade de maputo (na casa oferecida). Não vive com o pai dos filhos. Sobrevive de aluguer de um imóvel que fora oferecida por seu avo na cidade de maputo que aluga e rende 12.000,00MT por mês e aplica na construção da casa de alvenaria em fases, assim com pagamento de despesas familiares.

Aprendeu a fazer negócios (venda de produtos diversos) na cidade de maputo, antes de se transferir para Boane onde vive há mais de 10 anos.

Este é o primeiro empréstimo da Aureca na Hluvuku-Adsema no valor de 12.000,00MT para compra de material de construção (cimento, areia e outros) com intuito de finalizar a obra de construção de casa de alvenaria.

Tem como plano futuro, concluir a obra e construir uma mercearia e para tal propõe se a reembolsar o empréstimo sem problema para poder aceder a mais empréstimos.
texts.en:
Aurea was born in the northern province of Zambezia, in the city of Quelimae. She is 29 years old, and a single mother of 2 children aged 6 months and 10. She attended school through the tenth grade but dropped out due to respiratory problems. She lives in her own home with her children. She also supports her mother, who still lives in her native province of Zambezia, by sending money to her at the end of every month. Aurea did not grow up with her parents. When she was still a baby she went to live in the Inhambane province with friends, and later lived in the city of Maputo (in a home left to her). She does not live with the father of her children. She lives off the rent she earns from a building that was left to her by her grandfather in the city of Maputo, which she rents out, earning 12.000,00MT monthly. She is using the money to build a brick home in phases, and to cover family expenses. She learned to run a business (selling a variety of products) in the city of Maputo, before moving to Boane where she has lived for more than 10 years. This is Aurea's first loan with Hluvuku-Adsema, in the amount of 12.000,00MT. It will be used to purchase construction materials (cement, sand, etc.) with the goal of completing construction on her home. Her future plans are to finish her home and build a small store. To do this she plans to repay the loan without any problems so that she can have access to future loans.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchae of construction materials (cement, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Mariana Califonha

texts.pt:
Mariana nasceu na província de Tete, no norte de Moçambique, (onde se localiza a hidroelétrica de cahora-bassa, uma das maiores de áfrica). Tem 53 anos de idade, casado e mãe de 7 filhos com idades compreendidas entre 7 e 22 anos que freqüentam escolas publicas de boane. Vive com mais um sobrinho que esta sob sua responsabilidade. Estudou ate 3 classe do tempo colonial e parou quando contraiu grávida. Mais tarde ingressou nas fileiras das forcas armadas de libertação Nacional, para a independência do pais do jugo colonial.

Vive na casa própria com sua família (marido, filhos e sobrinho). Para alem da família cuida da sua mãe no mesmo espaço físico da casa.

Saiu de Tete no ano de 1981 a boane, sozinha, ao encontro do seu marido que encontrava se em missão de serviço militar. Mariana também  foi militar, combatente da luta de libertação nacional juntamente com seu marido e ambos são pensionistas do ministério da defesa nacional. Conheceram se na tropa antes do fim da guerra.
Cada um recebe 5.740,00MT e totalizam 11.480,00MT, mensalmente, que aplicam no sustento da família e construção da casa de alvenaria.

Teve credito com outras instituições similares e diz que ouviu falar da Hluvuku-Adsema através dos vizinhos e clientes da instituição que acharam a  modalidade de pagamento democrático (o cliente define o valor de pagamento mensal segundo as suas capacidades e pode fechar antes do tempo sem penelização ).

Este vai ser o segundo empréstimo da Mariana na instituição no valor de 12.000,00MT para compra de material de construção (cimento, areia e outros). O primeiro credito de 10.000,00MT também foi para a mesma actividade. 

Propõe se a pagar o empréstimo sem problemas para poder aceder a mais créditos com intuito de concluir a obra e fortalecer o negocio.
texts.en:
Mariana was born in the Tete province, in northern Mozambique (where the Cahora-Bassa hydroelectric dam is located, one of the largest in Africa.) She is 53 years old, and is married with 7 children between ages 7 and 22. Her children attend public schools in Boane. She also supports one of her nephews who lives with her. She attended school until the third grade during the colonial era, but stopped when she became pregnant. Later she enlisted in the armed forces of the national liberation, for independence from the colonial yoke. She lives in her own home with her family (husband, children, and nephew). She also cares for her mother in her home. She left Tete in 1981 for Boane, alone, to meet up with her husband who was in the military. Mariana was also in the military, and fought for independence along with her husband. Both she and her husband receive a pension from the Ministry of National Defense. They met in the military before the end of the war. Each of them receives 5.740.00MT monthly, totaling 11.480.00MT, which they use to support their family and for construction of a cement block home. Mariana had loans with other similar institutions and said that she heard about Hluvuku-Adsema through two neighbors who were clients of Hluvuku-Adsema and found the payment method to be democratic (the client defines the monthly payment in accordance with his/her ability to pay and can pay off the loan early without any penalties). This will be Mariana's second loan, in the amount of 12.000,00MT for the purchase of construction materials (cement, sand, etc.). Her first loan was for 10.000,00MT for the same purposes. She plans to pay back the loan without any problems in order to have access to additional loans to finish her home and strengthen her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Hilaha

texts.en:
Hilaha J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Hilaha is 29 years old and married with a husband who is a businessman. They have two children who both attend school.  With the extra profits that will result from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

About BRAC:
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Mugoma Women’S Group

texts.en: Grace S., the leader of Mugoma Women’s Group, is 38 years old and married with seven children and six additional dependents who all attend school. She has been in the business of selling cassava flour for over six months.  She will use the loan to increase and expand her business by purchasing four or five bags of cassava flour to resell. This will enable her to earn more profits and educate her children. She is a very hardworking woman and she encourages her fellow women to work hard. Her dream for the future is to see her children become well-educated.

loans.use: To purchase four or five bags of cassava flour.

loans.name: Mami

texts.en:
Mami R. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phaste and is requesting a loan to purchase baking materials .  

Mami is 39 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant . She has 4 children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bigger backery.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase baking materials

loans.name: Mugoma Women’S Group Bonabona Neima

texts.en: B. Neima is twenty-three years old representing her group loan. She is married with three children and they are all in school. She also has three dependents. She sells produces that is bananas. She has been in this bananas business for one year. She is using the loan in order to add capital to her business so that she can be able to purchase bananas in much more numbers. She is very active and so hopeful for the loan to boost her business. Her dream is educating her children.

loans.use: To add capital to her business so that she can be able to purchase bananas in much more numbers.

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre N. is 41 years old, is single, and he takes care of four dependents aged between 33 and 8.

Jean Pierre has been in a restaurant business for the past four years. He employs five people who work from 5:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m.

It is after a big desire of increasing his restaurant size and improving the quality of service, be it on food or buying some new restaurant materials, that Jean Pierre is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company. 

By receiving and using this new loan, Jean Pierre hopes to get as many clients as possible and, after that, he hopes to earn enough profit to help him to buy a house.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for his restaurant

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana sells baby goods like flasks, creams, and diapers to make a living and this is her main source of income. She has been in this business for a long time.

She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is 42 years old and is married with three children. She hopes to receive a loan amount of ₦140,000 to purchase more baby goods to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby goods to sell

loans.name: Nyamitoma United Grace Mabiho Group

texts.en:
Grace M. is a forty year old business woman. She is married and has six children who are all in school. She has a total of ten dependents. She has been operating a retail shop for ten years and wants to add capital to her business by purchasing more retail stock such as Jeri cans of cooking oil, boxes of soap, bags of sugar and rice.

She is a hard working woman who is willing to double her efforts in order to make her business prosperous. Her dreams are to educate her children and improve the standard of living in her home.

loans.use: To add capital to her business by purchasing more retail stock.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is sixty years old. She is a widow and has four children who are all out of school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town.

Mary is a trader who trades in vegetables such as peppers. She sells vegetables at the local market and supplies them to retailers and food vendors in her community. She also treks to other markets to sell vegetables. She buys her goods from nearby towns.

Mary has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy vegetables in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy vegetables in bulk to expand her business.

loans.name: Costa

texts.en: Costa is a 43 year married with six children aged between 4and 20 years All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members (her brother’s children). Costa resides and owns three roomed house where she is staying with ten people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week. Costa owns fries eatables like samosas chapatti and mandazi and moves Door to Door in Kawempe. She buys and doesn’t pay rent for business premises She uses public transport to and from shopping.  She sells to all categories of people and on both retail and whole saleCosta has been with MCDT for eight year servicing her twenty fourth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to stock more baking flour cooking oil and cow peas She is aspiring of employing at least 20 employees.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil andbaking flour

loans.name: Precious

texts.en: Precious is a mother of a child and she is 28 years old. She sells electronics at Alaba International market in Lagos state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for long. She hopes for the loan amount of N160, 000 to purchase more electronics to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Nyamutoma United Tibasaga Joyce Group

texts.en: T. Joyce is a representative of her loan group, she is married with four children all schooling and have four dependents of which two are schooling. She deals with the selling of used shoes since the year 2002. She is using the loan to purchase used shoes from Owino market mostly shoes for children and sells them in Kachwamba which is almost 312 kilometers away from Kampala town. She is looking forward to widening her business and her dreams are to manage her business well and educate her children too.

loans.use: To purchase used shoes from Owino market mostly shoes for children and sells them in Kachwamba

loans.name: Fransisca

texts.en: Fransisca sells cooked foods and drinks in her shop. The demands for her cooked foods are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is 38 years old and married with 2 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase a generator because there is constant power failure in her community. This she says will enable her sell cold drinks to her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase a generator

loans.name: Humura Nyakasanja United Muziguzi Perisi Group

texts.en: M. Perisi is the group President of Humura Nyakasanja United; she is thirty-nine years old single woman with four children of which three are going to school. She has one dependent schooling too. She deals with retail shop and also she is a tailor. She is using the loan to purchase essential items mostly that is sugar, rice, soap, salt, etc in her shop. She wants to add stock to improve upon her business. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to purchase a car.

loans.use: To purchase essential items mostly that is sugar, rice, soap, salt, etc in her shop.

loans.name: Okeke

texts.en: Okeke sells palm oil in both the wholesale and retail markets. Palm oil is used in the preparation of local soups like egusi, okro, etc. She is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N 100,000 to purchase more palm oil to sell. She would like to say "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil to sell.

loans.name: Uwimpeta

texts.en:
J. Uwimpeta is 28 years old, is married, and she takes care of two orphans, 21 and 18 years old.

J. has owned a hardware shop for the past two years, working eleven hours a day, though the items to sell are still few.

After realizing that she has few items in her hardware shop, she is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company to purchase more items to sell.

Through accessing this new loan, J. plans to help her husband buy a house and help her two orphans attend university.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Juliet's Group

texts.en:
B. Juliet is the leader of her lending group in Ntungamo. She is 58 years old and a widow with 6 children between the ages of 20 and 14. She is also the caretaker for two of her grandparents.

B. has been operating a bar, a hotel and a retail shop in the Itojo trading center for 23 years now. Although she makes 130,000 Ugandan shillings in profits per week, the combination of her debt and overhead costs are still more than her income, which forces her to continue to borrow from Pearl microfinance.

Juliet has a dream of expanding her businesses in order to put her children through school. She needs a loan to purchase inventory: crates of beverages.

loans.use: To purchase inventory (crates of beverages).

loans.name: David

texts.en: S. David is an individual client that has been working with Pearl microfinance for 4 years now. He is a married man with 4 children the eldest being at the University and his dream is to see all the four attaining the best of education. He is a farmer involved in banana growing in Rubaare, Kagongi Cell for 20 years and he is grateful that at least every week, he has a net profit of 50,000/=, because of the quality of his produce. He is mainly affected by the unstable prices of produce that keep on changing depending on the season and it is good that for such seasons, he plans accordingly. He wants to live a happy life together with his family since they have gone through a lot together. He needs a loan to help improve his banana plantation by buying farm inputs for improved quality and quantity.

loans.use: Buying farm inputs for an improved farm for more revenue.

loans.name: Godelive

texts.en:
Godelive M. is a widow, 41 years old, and she takes care of four children aged between 12 and 6.

Godelive has been selling for fifteen years by working from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. She is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more goods in order to earn more profit than before. With that profit, Godelive hopes to pay school fees and get more food for her family.

Through accessing this new loan, Godelive has a hope for the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Zenobia

texts.es:
Zenobia es socia del Banco Comunal Minka.
Zenobia es soltera, tiene 40 años y 2 hijos, Zenobia tiene una bodega en su casa en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, frutas, gas, carnes, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de su hijo, además Zenobia viaja a las ferias de donde compra cereales.
Zenobia necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azucar, arroz y bebidas.
Los sueños de Zenobia son aumentar su negocio y salir adelante trabajando.
texts.en:
Zenobia is a member of Minka Communal Bank. She is single, 40 years old, and has 2 children.

Zenobia has a store in her house where she sells groceries, vegetables, fruits, soft drinks and meat. She operates the store every day with the help of her son. She also travels to markets where she buys grains to sell.

Zenobia needs a loan of 1000 soles that she will invest in buying sugar, rice and drinks. Her dreams are to grow her business and to get ahead by working.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of sugar, rice, and drinks.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is twenty – nine years old. She is married and has give birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. She is a trader. Grace trades in food stuffs such as plantain. She sells at the local market and supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. She buys her goods from nearby towns. Grace has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy plantain in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela es socia del Banco Comunal Minka.
Marcela es casada, tiene 33 años y 4 hijos, Marcela vende ollas renaware por catálogos, además vende ropa a pedido, productos que adquiere en la ciudad de Lima, sus ventas son al crédito. Marcela tiene proyectado implementar una fuente de soda en su casa.
Marcela necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de chompas.
Los sueños de Marcela son que sus hijos salgan adelante y tener una fuente de soda.

loans.use: Para la compra de chompas.

loans.name: Matayo's Group

texts.en: N. Matayo is the leader of his lending group in Ntungamo. He is a married man with 4 children aged between 12 – 6 children all in primary school. He is a manager for happy Christians, a money lending Sacco in Ntungamo town and his profits depend on the money lent out. The way he operates is that he gets money and lends out to the others for very short terms and this is how he earns a living for 7 years. In addition to this, he is a farmer and sells out his produce for money although he employs people to work on his farm most of the times. He has a dream of transforming his Sacco into a bank so that he could make more money as he reaches out to many. Matayo needs a loan to help expand his business by employing more labor on his farm so that he could lend money to more people.

loans.use: Employing manpower on his farm.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 29 years old. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Wiawso, a commercial and farming town in the Western Region of Ghana. 

Rebecca sells textiles at the local market. She also treks to nearby towns to sell on their market days. She buys her goods from nearby towns. Rebecca has been in business for four years and wants a loan to buy textile materials in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy textiles

loans.name: Yola America

texts.es:
Yola es socia del Banco Comunal Minka.
Yola es casada, tiene 57 años y 3 hijos, Yola tiene una hamburguesería llamada Yoli, en un local alquilado, actividad que realiza todos los días por las noches, para lo cual cuenta con 8 personas que apoyan.
Yola necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de hamburguesas y papas.
Los sueños de Yola son acompañar a sus nietos.
texts.en:
Yola is a member of the Minka Communal Bank. Yola is 57 years old and married with three children. She has a burger restaurant called Yoli in a rented location and works there every night, employing eight people to help her. Yola needs a load of 1600 soles, which will be invested in the purchase of hamburgers and potatoes. Yola's dream is to spend time with her grandchildren.

Translated from Spanish by Amanda McDermott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: for the purchase of hamburgers and potatoes

loans.name: Maximo

texts.es:
Máximo es socio del Banco Comunal Minka.
Máximo es casado, tiene 60 años y 3 hijos, Máximo tiene una panificadora en su casa, donde elaboran panes típicos como el chapla,  el horno es rustico a leña, sus ventas los realiza en el mercado magdalena.
Máximo necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de harina, azúcar y leña.
Los sueños de Máximo son mejorar su negocio y tener maquinas para su panificadora.

loans.use: Para la compra de harina, azúcar y leña.

loans.name: Kadiku

texts.en: Kadiku sells juice and drinks to make a living. Kadiku is a widow and she is very strong and focused on pulling her family out of poverty. Kadiku is 45 years old and she has three children. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 nairas to purchase more juice and drinks to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more juice and drinks to sell

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida is thirty – three years old. She is married and has give birth to four children, all in school. Vida lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. She is a baker. She bakes bread and supplies to retailers in her community. She buys her goods from nearby towns. Vida has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour

loans.name: Wankinnou

texts.fr: H. Wankinnou est née vers 1950 à Ouidah. Wankinnou est mariée à ACCROMBESSI Hounye. Ce couple a à sa charge quatre enfants tous scolarisés dont deux sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis cinq ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Wankinnou vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Wankinnou vend des produits de soins corporels, principalement le savon de toilette produit au Ghana, un pays voisin du Bénin. Wankinnou vend aussi des ustensiles de cuisines. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Wankinnou achète ses produits. Wankinnou a déjà quinze ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Wankinnou a eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité, Wankinnou demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de savon de Ghana et de produits de soins corporels.

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en: M. Mary is 44 years old and a widow with 6 children aged between 22 – 8 years and all still in school. She also takes care of 3 orphans. Mary is a business lady and a matooke dealer who buys her produce from villages to her stall in Kyeizinga I for 8 years so far and she is mostly affected by the poor roads making transportation difficult. She is able to make 50,000/= as profits a week and this is basically with the good customer care and the loans that help to increase stock. She has a dream of opening up a retail shop in addition to her current business as well as continue educating her children. She needs a loan to help pay school fees for her children as well as restock her business with more produce.

loans.use: Paying school fees for the children and buying more matooke for resale.

loans.name: Fredy

texts.es:
Fredy es socio del Banco Comunal Minka.
Fredy es soltero, tiene 32 años y 5 hijos, de profesión profesor, Fredy viaja a la selva ayacuchana de donde compra maní, cacao, productos que comercializa en la ciudad de Huancayo. Fredy tiene proyectado iniciar con la venta de bebidas.
Fredy necesita un préstamo de 800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de bebidas.
Los sueños de Fredy son tener una empresa y hacer obras de bien social.

loans.use: Para la compra de bebidas.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is fifty-nine years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. She is a trader. Elizabeth trades in utensils. She sells at the local market and hawks to sell in her community. She also treks to other towns to sell. Elizabeth buys her goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy all kinds of utensils in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy utensils

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
Juliana es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Juliana es casada, tiene 48 años y 4 hijos, Juliana viaja a las diferentes ferias de la region en donde vende ropa y de las ferias compra papa, quesos, productos que vende en diferentes pueblos.
Juliana necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de falda, pantalón.
Juliana sueña con mejorar su negocio, comprar una mototaxi para que su hijo trabaje.

loans.use: Para la compra de falda, pantalón.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.es:
Jacinta es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Jacinta es casada, tiene 60 años y 6 hijos, Jacinta viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde vende frutas, lanas y de las ferias compra cereales que vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad.
Jacinta necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de trigo, cebada.
Los sueños de Jacinta son construir su casa y mejorar su negocio.

loans.use: Para la compra de trigo, cebada.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is fifty-nine years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Comfort runs a licensed chemist store. She sells all kinds of drugs, both tablets and syrups alike. She sells in a store by the road side in her community. Comfort buys her goods from nearby towns and from distribution vans. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy drugs in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy drugs

loans.name: Reyna Isabel

texts.es:
Reyna es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Reyna es conviviente, tiene 32 años y 2 hijos, Reyna junto a su hermana tienen una tienda en un local alquilado, Reyna vende pollo, carnes. Además tiene 2 mototaxis, con uno de ellos trabaja su esposo y el otro lo alquila.
Reyna necesita un préstamo de 2500 soles dinero que será invertido en la reparación de las motos.
Los sueños de Reyna son comprar otro mototaxi y salir adelante.

loans.use: Para la reparación de las motos.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Julia es soltera, tiene 64 años y 2 hijas, Julia viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde vende ropa, y de las ferias compra cereales, animales, queso, productos que vende en los mercados y de casa en casa.
Julia necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de mandiles, chompas, blusas.
Los sueños de Julia son construir su casa y tener una tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of the Triumph Community Bank. She is single, 64 years old, and has two daughters. Julia travels to different fairs of the region where she sells clothes. At the fairs she buys grain, animals, and cheese, all products she sells in the markets and door to door.

Julia needs a loan of $575 to buy aprons, sweaters, and blouses. Her dreams are to build her house and to have a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY APRONS, SWEATERS, AND BLOUSES TO SELL

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is forty years old. She is married and has given birth to five children, who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Mary is a trader. She is involved in a local soap production business. She sells at the local market and supplies to other retailers in her community. Mary buys her goods such as soda ash, palm oil, etc. from nearby towns. She has been in business for some years and wants a loan to buy raw materials in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy soda ash and palm oil for her soap production busines

loans.name: Cécile

texts.fr: H. Cécile est née vers 1984 à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Cécile est mariée à BOKI Victorin, un farailleur. Ce couple a à sa charge trois enfants tous scolarisés dont un seul est le leur. La famille réside depuis six ans à Fridjrossè, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Cécile vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Cécile vend des mèches de coiffure et des produits cosmétiques. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin et au Nigeria, un Etat voisin du Bénin que Cécile achète ses produits et elle les vend de façon ambulante. Cécile a déjà huit ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Cécile a déjà eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité, Cécile demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Cécile H. was born in 1984 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Cécile is married to Victorin BOKI, a scrap dealer. This couple is financially responsible for three children, only one is theirs, all attend school. The family has lived in Fridjrossè, a neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Bénin.

Thanks to the income from her business, Cécile helps her husband provide for their family. Cécile sells hair extensions and cosmetic products. Cécile buys her supplies in Dantokpa, a large international market in Bénin, and in Nigeria, a neighboring state of Bénin. She is a door to door saleswoman. Cécile already has eight years of experience in this business. She has received two loans from Alidé, both have been fully reimbursed, and she used those to bolster the level of her activity. To continue to increase her activity, Cécile is asking for a third loan in order to strengthen her working capital.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair extensions and cosmetics

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en: Bolaji sells clothes and she is also a fashion designer. Bolaji has been in this business for long. She is 45 years old and married with 2 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N70, 000 to purchase more clothes and tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Brigitte

texts.fr: H. Brigitte est née vers 1961 à Abomey. Brigitte est mariée à HOUNDEDJI Joseph, un boulanger. Ce couple a à sa charge sept enfants tous scolarisés dont cinq sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis vingt deux ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. C’est le mari de Brigitte qui assure les charges de la famille.  Ceci permet à Brigitte d’utiliser les revenus de son activité pour mieux développer celle-ci. Brigitte vend des divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.), des cartes de recharge téléphonique et de la nourriture (riz et haricot) devant chez elle à la maison. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Brigitte achète ses produits. Brigitte a déjà quinze d’expérience dans cette activité. Brigitte a déjà eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité, Brigitte demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de pâtes alimentaires de boîtes de conserves, de savon, d’insecticides, de sacs de riz et de haricot, etc.

loans.name: Ziporah's Group

texts.en:
L. Ziporah has been a medical worker and birth attendant in Ibanda for over 30 years. She needs a loan to help expand her business by buying more supplies like gloves and drugs for her medical centre. She is a good lady who knows how to handle her clients, and this has won her many genuine friends. She is able to make 300,000/= in profit a month.

L. Ziporah is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is a 51-year-old lady, married, with six children all in primary school, and she takes care of three dependants. Her major goal is to improve her business by providing quality services and to ensure that her family is happy and healthy.

loans.use: To buy more supplies like gloves and drugs for her medical centre

loans.name: Lunsar Group

texts.en:
This is Isatu S., Isatu K., Ramatu K. and Marie K.. They call their group Lunsar Group, named after the home town of the group’s leader. They are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva for the first time to seek a loan of Le 500,000 for each to help them develop their businesses. With the help of this loan, their businesses will increase both in size and quality, attracting more customers so that sales will improve, profit will also increase and consequently improving on their standard of living.

Isatu S. (left) is the leader of this group. She is approximately fifty-five years of age, married to a businessman and they have five children, who are now all grown-ups. Isatu sells market food like rice, onions, pepper, salts, etc. She also sells cigarette and flour. Isatu has been a businesswoman for over thirty years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Clarisse

texts.fr: S. Clarisse est née le 01/01/1980 à Cotonou, Capitale économique du Bénin. Clarisse est mariée à DANSI Ignace, un couturier. Ce couple a à sa charge sept enfants tous scolarisés dont trois sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis quinze ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Clarisse vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. C’est des tissus et des vêtements que Clarisse vend de façon ambulante. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin et à Lomé, pays voisin du Bénin que Clarisse achète ses produits. Clarisse a déjà quinze d’expérience dans cette activité. Clarisse a eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité, Clarisse demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de tissus et de vêtements.

loans.name: Hard Working Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Hard Working group. They are small scale businessmen in Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of Le 500,000 for each to enable them improve their businesses. With a loan, they will be able to add more goods into their businesses, make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living standard will improve so that they can better look after themselves and children. 

The leader of this group is Foday T. (left). He was born in Magburaka town and is now twenty-five years old. He is married with two children – one in nursery and the other is still suckling. Foday is a driver; he has been in this profession for four years now. With this loan, he will use it to buy tires and sell to fellow drivers.

loans.use: Buy tires to sell

loans.name: Candida

texts.es:
La Señora Cándida de 48 años de edad,  es comerciante,  esta casada con el Señor Dionicio hace más de 30 años con quien tuvo 5 hijos.
 Comenzó su actividad en el año 2.006, con mucho esfuerzo y la ayuda de  su marido quien trabaja como albañil y también el apoyo incondicional de sus hijos, José de  28 años de edad quien también es albañil, Nancy de 25 años quien es docente, Juana de 24 años quien se encuentra trabajando en España, Enrique de 19 años  y Juan de 12 años de edad quien está cursando el sexto grado de la Educación Básica. 
Comenta que hoy en día cuenta con una despensa muy surtida y que se vió en la necesidad de ampliar su salón comercial debido a que posee gran demanda de mercaderías de todo tipo, por tal motivo su stock ha aumentado considerablemente en los últimos tiempos.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción para terminar su salón comercial.
La misma  agradece la oportunidad brindada por la Fundación Paraguaya, ya que  gracias a eso logrará terminar su nuevo local incrementando sus mercaderías y con ello sus ventas para su bienestar y de toda su familia.
texts.en:
Cándida is 48 years old and a shopkeeper. She and her husband Dionicio have been married for over 30 years and have 5 children. She began her business in 2006 with great personal effort, along with help from her husband, who works as a mason. She also benefited from the unconditional support of her children: José, age 28, who is also a mason; Nancy, age 25, a teacher; Juana, 24, who is currently working in Spain; Enrique, age 19; and Juan, who is 12 and currently in the sixth grade. She reports that she currently stocks a very broad range of products, and there has been great demand among customers for merchandise of all types. For this reason, she has increased her stock considerably in recent times, and she has seen the need to expand her store to accommodate these products. She is requesting this loan to purchase construction materials to complete the expansion of her store. Cándida appreciates the opportunity provided by the Fundación Paraguaya, which will allow her to complete the construction of her new facility, expand her stock and thus increase her sales, in order to support her own well-being and that of her entire family.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Completing the construction of her store

loans.name: Innocent's Group

texts.en: T. Innocent is 30 years old and the leader of his lending group in Ibanda. He is a married man with 4 children all in primary and secondary schools as he also takes care of 4 dependants. Innocent has a hard ware shop in Engabisya trading center that has been running for over 10 years and he is able to make 400,000/= as monthly profits. He is a friendly and hard working man with a strong drive to succeed. He needs a loan to help restock his hard ware shop with more products like cement, iron sheets and bars in order to avoid a shortage. He is such a grateful man for the loans disbursed to him and his group members.

loans.use: Buying more hard ware equipment for increased stock.

loans.name: Obanla

texts.en: Obanla sells clothes, shoes and bags to make a living. She is 42 years old and married with three children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is requesting a loan of 70,000 nairas to purchase more clothes, shoes and bags to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos tiene 45 años de edad, está casado con  Ramona de 42 años, ambos conviven juntos hace más de 20 años y poseen dos  hijos de 19  y 16 años, el mayor ya terminó sus estudios secundarios y el segundo sigue estudiando en un colegio nacional de la ciudad.
 Carlos se dedicó a la costura desde muy pequeño por que era una profesión que su padre lo ejercía, comenta además que vivió en la Argentina por muchos años, realizando trabajos   con su hermano mayor, de profesión costurero. Trabajó como 9 años más o menos y del capital que pudo ahorrar vino a montar  su propio taller junto con su señora que también le ayuda en dicha profesión. 
En la actualidad ellos mismos se dedican a confeccionar todo tipo de prendas como son: pantalones, camisas, camperas, remeras deportivas entre otros  artículos, y luego sus hijos se encargan de venderlos a diferentes puntos del país. 
Está muy conforme con su actividad por que gracias a ella pudo hacer estudiar a todos sus hijos, como así también gracias a su sacrificio y esfuerzo en el trabajo hoy día posee todos los artículos de primera necesidad  en su hogar. 
En esta oportunidad solicita el préstamo para la compra de materia prima como: telas, hilos y otros materiales que utiliza en su trabajo, debido a que si compra en mayor cantidad le sale mucho mas barato.

loans.use: Compra de telas e hilos.

loans.name: Love Each Other Group

texts.en:
Hawanatu K., Zainab M. B., Aminata K. and Alie T. have formed a group, which they call "Love Each Other." They are entrepreneurs in the town of Magburaka, which is about fifteen miles from Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone.

Hawanatu K. (left) is 22 years old, a native of Magburaka and the leader of the group. She is divorced and has one child who is in nursery school. Hawanatu has been selling bowls, buckets, dishes, bags, and sandals for three years now.

This will be Love Each Other's first loan from SMT/Kiva. They will use the funds to expand their businesses and to increase their income, which will allow them to take better care of themselves and their children.

loans.use: To expand the businesses and increase income.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos tiene 42 años de edad, vive en pareja con  Estela de 40 años, ambos conviven hace más de 10 años y poseen un hijo de 7 años que va a la escuela primaria. 
 Carlos desde muy pequeño se dedicó a la carpintería, comenzó trabajando como ordenanza, después de varios años de trabajo fue ascendiendo ya como carpintero profesional, trabajó muy duro durante 18 años y con el ahorro que pudo juntar durante esos años  decidió independizare. 
 Tal es así que hoy día cuenta con su propia carpintería, negocio que le va muy bien por que gracias a su esfuerzo constante consiguió muy buena clientela y tiene trabajo durante todo el año. Todos los días empieza su trabajo desde muy temprana horas del día. 
Esta muy conforme con su actividad como carpintero por que es una profesión que siempre le ha gustado y además posee el apoyo de su señora. 
En esta oportunidad solicita el préstamo para la compra de más  materia prima (madera) debido a que tiene una oferta que quiere aprovechar.

loans.use: Compra de madera.

loans.name: Tamaraneh Traders Group

texts.en:
Here are Memuna T., Kadiatu S., Adama T., Zainab S. and Marie K.. They are members of the Tamaraneh Traders group. This will be the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. They have been in business for many years now but business has been developing at a very slow pace. They have thus come to SMT/Kiva to seek a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean leone for each to help them improve their businesses. 

Memuna T. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. Memuna was born in the village of Mayolo, on the outskirts of Magburaka town, about 55 years ago. She is married with nine children: five are already grown-ups, one is in Junior Secondary School III (JSS III), while the others are in JSS II, JSS I and class I. 

Memuna owns a small kiosk in Mayolo village where she sells stuff like cigarettes, biscuits, batteries, mints, lighters, etc. Memuna has been a businesswoman since her childhood days. She will use this loan to expand her business, as she believes that the bigger the business capital, the faster the business will grow.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: T. Martine est née vers 1972 à Tori Bossito. Martine est mariée à ABAKPE Lambert, un menuiser. Ce couple a à sa charge quatre enfants tous scolarisés dont deux sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis sept ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Martine vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Martine vend des chaussures de façon ambulante. C’est à Lomé, pays voisin du Bénin que Martine achète ses produits. Martine a déjà dix ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Martine a déjà eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour continuer à développer son activité, Martine demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de chaussures.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sariyat

texts.en: Sariyat sells food items and provisions in her shop in Lagos State, Nigeria. Sariyat is 48 years old, married, and has nine children. She hopes to receive a loan amount of ₦50,000 to purchase more food items and provisions to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more food items and provisions to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 41 years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. 

Mary is a trader. She trades in all kinds of underwear for both males and females. She sells at the local market and treks to other towns to sell as well. She also trades in cosmetics. Mary buys her goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for one year and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy underwear in bulk

loans.name: God Bless Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “God Bless” Group. They are small-scale businesswomen in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva for the first time to seek a loan of Le 500,000 for each to invest into their businesses.

Memunatu B. is the leader of this group. Memunatu was born in a village call Masomri, in northern Sierra Leone. She is an approximately 55 year old widow with five children. Three of her children are grown-ups and two are in secondary schools.

Memunatu B. sells dried fish and has been a businesswoman since her childhood days. With this loan, she will be able to buy a basket full of dried fish from a village called Thongo and sell the fish in Magburaka town and in villages around the town.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi is thirty-six years old. She is married and has give birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Naomi is a trader. She is involved in a local soap production business. She sells at the local market and supplies to other retailers in her community. She buys her goods such as soda ash, palm oil, etc. from nearby towns. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy raw materials in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy soda ash and palm oil for her soap production busines

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena is twenty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Abena is a trader. She runs a cold store. She sells at the local market and supplies to other retailers and food vendors in her community. Abena buys her goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy cartons of fish in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish

loans.name: Ca´acupemí Group

texts.es:
Ca´acupemí se denomina el grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Capiatá en fecha 24 de febrero de 2.009 gracias a que la actual Directora de Finanzas, la Sra. Reinalda Sández, contactó con la asesora en una de las reuniones semanales que la misma tenía en la zona para enterarse mejor de la forma de trabajo que tiene el comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. Una vez asesorada logró juntar 20 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto y en forma solidaria dentro del programa.
El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de 445.000 Gs., lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de comidas, venta de mercerías, venta de mercaderías para la despensa (arroz, azúcar, fideos, lácteos, panificados, yerba, etc.), venta de accesoR. para celulares, venta de chipa, venta de productos de limpieza, venta de artículos de madera, venta de ropas, venta de platería, venta de perfumes, venta de aceites, etc. 
Todas ellas están ayudándose mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya. 
El detalle de actividades según cada señora es el siguiente:
Reinalda Sández	Venta de comidas 
Adriana C. 	Venta de aceite 
Clara R.	Despensa
Miguela Fernández	Venta de comestibles
Diana Almeida	Compra y vta. de reciclados. 
Manuela C.	Venta de artículos de madera. 
María González	Venta. de productos de limpieza. 
Graciela S.	Venta de ropas
Andrea C.	Venta de perfumes
Ramona A.	Venta de Chipa
Efigenia V.	Venta de comidas
María Y.	Venta de ropas
Benita T.	Costurera
Juliana F.	Venta de ropas
Mirian D.	Venta de comidas
Sunilce Sánchez	Venta de mercerías
Graciela Ríos	Venta de accesoR. para celulares. 
Dominga P.	Venta de mercerías
María A.	Vta. de platería
Jacinta G.	Despensa

loans.use: compra de mercaderías varias para la venta como comestibles, bebidas, perfumes, ropas, etc.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr: T. Jacqueline est née vers 1964 à Tori Bossito. Jacqueline est mariée à KINLIN Vincent, un menuisier. Ce couple a à sa charge sept enfants tous scolarisés dont quatre sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis quarante ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Jacqueline vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Jacqueline vend des chaussures et des sacs de sortie à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Jacqueline achète ses produits à Lomé, pays voisin du Bénin. Jacqueline a déjà dix ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Jacqueline a eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour continuer à développer son activité, Jacqueline demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de sacs de sortie et de chaussures.

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
Francisco Javier S. C. de 31 años de edad, proviene de la ciudad de Masaya, de la parte céntrica donde sobresale la artesanía, como lo son el trabajo en cuero, barro, camba entre otros.

Francisco es la cabeza de una familia joven formada por su hija de 6 años a quien le dedica su vida y trabajo y su esposa quien lo ha apoyado en sus proyectos y sueños. Él posee un taller artesanal, donde trabaja en la elaboración de calzado, como lo son Chinelas y zapato colegial. 

Aprendió el oficio, por que trabajó en un taller donde él era empleado o como ellos lo llaman “alistadores” (son quienes hacen toda la base del zapato, para luego entregársela a quien hace el acabado). Su tía distribuye calzado en diferentes zonas del país, entonces lo motivo a poner su propio taller, ofreciéndole ser ella quien le vendiera el zapato.

Francisco ha pasado situaciones muy difíciles, como lo fue cuando sufrió apendicitis y justo cuando se estaba recuperando su mamá falleció y ese golpe fue algo muy duro para su familia, pero sobre todo para él. A pesar de todo, con la ayuda de su esposa, el ánimo y el amor de su hija, decidió esforzarse mucho más y con los créditos han logrado poner una mini-pulpería.

Su crédito actual pretende invertirlo en acrecentar la mini-pulpería y en materia prima para su taller.
texts.en:
Francisco Javier S. C. is 31 years old, and comes from the central part of the City of Masaya. This area specializes in the production of handicrafts, such as leather work, pottery, plastic, and others. Francisco is the head of a young family which includes his daughter of 6 years, to whom he dedicates his life and work, and his wife, who has supported him in all of his projects and dreams. He owns a handicraft workshop, where he works making footwear, such as slippers and shoes for schoolchildren. He learned the trade because he worked as an employee in a workshop in the occupation that they call "alistadores" (this term refers to those who make the sole of the shoe, and later give it to those who finish it.) His aunt distributes shoes in different areas of the country; this motivated him to have his own workshop, since she offered to sell the shoes that he would produce. Francisco has passed through some difficult situations, as when he suffered appendicitis, and was just recovering when his mother died. This loss was very hard for his family, but most of all for him. In spite of this, with the help of his wife and the encouragement and love of his daughter, he decided to exert himself much more and, with the loans that he secured, establish a mini grocery store. The current loan will be invested in the growth of the mini grocery and in raw materials for his workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: products for the store and materials for the workshop

loans.name: Ireti

texts.en: Ireti sells drinks and provisions in her shop to make a living. She is 42 years old and married with 2 children. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to lift her family and business above poverty. Ireti hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia S. is a 63-year-old single woman who lives in the town of Moises Padilla, Negros Occidental. She has a nephew who lives with her and helps her, and she has accepted the responsibility of sending him to school. Her most cherished dream is have her business earn enough so that she will be able to afford to send her nephew to college.

Emilia has always had an entrepreneurial spirit and an independent outlook on life. She is willing to invest her time, effort and money in a business, when she is sure that she will profit from it. She started earning a living by putting up a small carinderia, or luncheonette, adjacent to her house to serve meals to the locals. It became so popular that she was inspired to expand her services and began to offer coffee and snacks between meal times. In 2002, she became a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could have access to additional capital to expand her business because, as she explains, "If you have a bigger investment [and] if you manage your business well, you will surely get a bigger return also." Over time, Emilia has saved up and bought properties as an investment to secure her future.

Aside from her luncheonette and cafeteria, Emilia earns additional income from two houses that she rents out. The smaller house is being rented by two students, while her bigger house is rented by a religious group. Emilia has been operating her carinderia and cafeteria for 32 years and she has been a landlord for only two. Her business nets her a profit of 4,000 pesos per month, which is enough for her living expenses, and she's been able to keep a good credit record with NWTF-Project Dungganon for the seven years that she's been a member. Her previous loan of 19,500 pesos for her 11th loan was fully repaid on time without any delays in any of her weekly installments.

Now for her 12th loan cycle, Emilia is again borrowing 19,500 pesos to add to her working capital to ensure the sustainability of her business.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: Additonal capital for her business

loans.name: Amarilis Del Establo Group

texts.es:
OLGA LIDIA V. T., A QUIEN APRECIAMOS EN LA FOTOGRAFÍA SENTADA; TIENE 26 AÑOS, ES MADRE SOLTERA Y TIENE TRES PEQUEÑOS HIJOS QUE SON SU RAZON DE SER Y EL ALICIENTE PARA TRABAJAR DURO,PARA PROGRESAR Y SACAR ADELANTE A SUS HIJOS.
ELLA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE ANTICUCHOS DE MANERA AMBULATORIA, UBICADA EN UNA AVENIDA PRINCIPAL, DESDE LAS 3 DE LA TARDE HASTA LAS 11 DE LA NOCHE.
LA SRA. OLGA,ES UNA MUJER QUE DESDE MUY PEQUEÑA HA TRABAJADO APOYANDO A SU PADRE EN ÉSTE NEGOCIO,ES POR ESO QUE AHORA, ELLA HA QUEDADO A CARGO YA QUE SU PAPI TIENE UNA EDAD AVANZADA, Y ADEMÁS PORQUE  NECESITABA TENER UN INGRESO PARA PODER MANTENER A SUS HIJOS.
NOS COMENTA LA SRA OLGA, QUE ELLA SIEMPRE HA SIDO MUY TRABAJADORA, LE HA GUSTADO GANAR SU DINERO CON MUCHO TRABAJO, Y SER INDEPENDIENTE. GRACIAS A SU ESFUERZO HA CONSEGUIDO COMPRAR ALGUNAS COSAS PARA SU CASA, DAR EDUCACIÓN A SUS PEQUEÑOS HIJOS Y MANTENER SU HOGAR SOLA.
SU META MAS CERCANA ES TENER UN LOCAL PROPIO DONDE PUEDA OFRECER Y ATENDER A SUS CLIENTES CON MAS COMODIDAD Y SOBRETODO, PARA QUE SUS HIJOS NO TENGAN QUE ESTAR EN LA CALLE MIENTRAS ESTÁ TRABAJANDO, YA QUE PARA PODER TRABAJAR, DEBE LLEVÁRSELOS CON ELLA PARA PODER CUIDARLOS MIENTRAS TRABAJA.
EL PRÉSTAMO SOLICITADO, LO INVERTIRÁ EN INSUMOS PARA LA PREPARACIÓN DE SUS ANTICUCHOS.
texts.en:
Olga Lidia V. T., who appears seated in the photograph, is 26 years old, a single mother of three small children that are her reason for being and her incentive to work hard and get them ahead. She makes a living selling grilled skewered meat at one of the main avenues, from 3 in the afternoon to 11 at night. Mrs. Olga has worked in this business since she was a child, helping her father. She is now in charge, since her father is now older, and she needs to have income to be able to support her children. Mrs. Olga tells us that she has always been very hard working. She likes to make money through hard work and be independent. Thanks to her efforts she has been able to buy some items for her home, provide an education for her small children and support her home by herself. Her current goal is to have her own place of business where she can offer her food and attend to her customers in comfort.
